Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Impact of Interorganizational Network Evolution on Outcomes for Nongovernmental Organizations (NGOs)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), governments, and businesses increasingly aim to form networks to address issues such as hunger, poverty, disease, and environmental degradation. Interorganizational networks enable constituencies to transcend some limitations and work toward common goals.

This research combines social network analysis methods with intensive assessment to (a) produce a reliable and valid measure of NGO capacity, and (b) test the common presumption that an NGO's capacity to address problems of disease and development is dependent on its local network of relationships with other NGOs, businesses, and government organizations.

The results of this study will include an important new outcome measure for NGO research. In addition, this project will identify the types of collaboration associated with increasing an NGO's scope of services, leadership strength, human resource capacity, financial stability, and research and advocacy capacity. This should have practical implications for better management of NGOs in context.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAREER: The Impact of Interorganizational Network Evolution on Outcomes for Nongovernmental Organizations (NGOs) examined the relationship between NGO, nongovernment organization (NGO) capacity and interorganizational network portfolios of NGO. NGO capacity is defined as the processes, practices, and people that the organization has at its disposal that enable it to produce, perform, or deploy resources to achieve its mission. This definition highlights that capacity ultimately is about an ability to accomplish organizational goals and mandates. In particular, a NGO’s capacity is linked to its ability to achieve its mission. Interorganizational network portfolios describe the number, type, character, and duration of relationships that organizations strategically maintain.

This research is important to scholars, funders, and policy makers. Scholars have been interested in the ways that NGO collaboration, including collaboration with other NGOs, businesses, and government agencies, influences organizational outcomes. Funders and policy makers are interested in the question because they have been encouraging NGO collaboration, without evidence that it yields better social service and NGO outcomes.

This 5-year project resulted in 17 academic publications and products. Three of these products are particular significant. The first was the development and validation of the NGO Capacities Instrument, a 49-item measure of eight NGO capacities. The capacities are (1) financial management, (2) adaptive capacity, (3) strategic planning, (4) external communication, (5) board leadership, (6) operational capacity, (7) mission orientation, and (8) staff management. This is the first reliable and valid measure of NGO capacity ever introduced.

Second, this project identified the three common interorganizational network portfolios that NGOs maintain. Due to limited resources, NGOs make strategic decisions on the number and quality of organizational partnerships across sectors (i.e., NGO, business, and government). Restricted within-sector portfolios have the fewest partnerships overall and only have collaborative relationships with other NGOs. In contrast, robust within-sector portfolios had the most relationships, but on average, only two cross-sector relationships that extend beyond funder-recipient. Comparatively, cross-sector portfolios contained more relationships with organizations in other sectors than with NGOs and 53% of those, on average, were more integrated than funder-recipient.

Third, this project demonstrates that NGO collaboration is not related to capacity, in the ways that were previously predicted. In particular, cross-sector collaboration (i.e., relationships between NGOs and business or NGOs and government agencies) case-based theory and research has long argued that NGOs that engage in more integrative and enduring cross-sector partnerships should increase their organizational capacity. This project examined whether this finding was generalizable across a large set of NGOs. It finds that cross-sector collaboration is not systematically related to increased capacity. However, more enduring relationships between government and NGO organizations that extend beyond funder–recipient relationships are related to greater strategic planning capacity.

Intellectual Merit

There have been two significant intellectual contributions to this project. First, empirically robust NGO research has been hampered by a variety of NGO capacity assessments that lack empirical validation. This project addressed this limitation by producing a reliable and valid measure of NGO capacity that demonstrated criterion validity by their relationship with several NGO outcome measures including self-reported measures of organizational effectiveness in comparison to peers.

Second, although previous research has examined trends in NGO collaboration, case studies of partnerships between NGOs and businesses, and the reported relationships between governments and NGOs, research that focuses on the outcomes of interorganizational networks for NGOs was lacking. The work debunks the myth that more collaboration leads to greater organizational capacity.

 Broader Impact

The research resulted in detailed reports being made available that compared the organizational capacity of 850 NGOs to each other. These customized reports were made available to each of the participating organization.

 A policy-brief was written and disseminated about the research. In particular, the policy brief draws attention to the inadequate measures of NGO capacity and effectiveness currently used by federal and international agencies. It describes the process that should be used to develop reliable and valid instruments.

Finally, the teaching component promotes equipped a new generation students with both analytical and practical skills for organizational innovation. The project has involved over 80 undergraduate students, five graduate students, and one post-doctoral research associate. Moreover, two students completed dissertations investigating the relationship between interorganizational collaboration and organizational outcomes.
